snippet: After four months of fighting in eastern Ukraine, few countries have chosen the word “invasion” to describe the slow-burning war.
abstract: Western leaders have largely avoided using the term 'invasion' to describe slow-burning conflict in Ukraine that has been fed by a steady flow of Russian weapons, tanks and soldiers across border; sidestepping of term highlights Russian Pres Vladimir Putin's success in blurring the boundary between war and peace, and points up a gulf of perception among Western allies as they gather for NATO summit meeting.

byline.contributor: Andrew E. Kramer contributed reporting from Novoazovsk, Ukraine; Alison Smale from Berlin; and Peter Baker from Washington.

lead_paragraph: After four months of fighting in eastern Ukraine, few countries have chosen the word “invasion” to describe the slow-burning war.

headline.main: On Ukraine, the West Sidesteps a Fraught Term
headline.print_headline: On Ukraine, the West Sidesteps a Fraught Term
